title: Wednesday, 3rd August, 2016

11:11 am
BE

BE

One could also read HSBC's own statement, which is relentlessly gloomy.

BE

11:13 am
BE

So instead, have some money. Have $2.5bn of it, current shareholders. Take it, go away and invest it in something else.

PM

hehehe

BE

Note the 10% ROE target's been pushed back.

11:14 am
BE

Actually, why am I trying to summarise the 300 or so pages that HSBC throws at us every quarter? There are people paid specifically to do that.

BE

Here's Deutsche Bank.

BE

HSBC has reported 2Q16 results this morning. Headline PBT is 12% weaker
than DBe and 7% weaker than consensus. But adjusting for revenue and cost
one-offs we have a 3% adjusted PBT beat vs. DBe and 9% adjusted beat vs.
consensus. This is driven by income 3% ahead, costs in line, better associate
income, partly offset by higher loan losses. By division u/l revenues were better
than expected in retail (4%), commercial (1%), GBM (1%) and GPB (1%) though
‘intersegmental revenue’ was more negative than expected, and ‘other’ more
positive. Capital 10bps better vs DBe at 12.1%, but NAV was 2% weaker QoQ

11:15 am
BE

Greater than 10% RoE target year of 2017 has been removed, though ambition of greater than 10% remains in the medium term. Company is citing low interest rate and economic
geo-political environment. Neither we nor consensus had HSBC hitting this target so this should not be a surprise. Dividends are to be held flat at 51c full year rather than progressive as previously (we were forecasting a 1c increase in each year). But company will be launching a US$2.5bn buyback (worth 23bps on capital 2% of the market cap) during 2H16. The board have PRA approval for this. This helps offset the dividend change: 51c dividend + US$2.5bn buyback = 10% yield this year, or around 7.5% cash yield after adjusting for dividend scrip. The question will be how sustainable this is, and whether there is potential for further buy-backs in 2017 / beyond.

BE

Overall, numbers were a beat, capital 10bps ahead, and market should not be
overly surprised on the dividend / ROE change. Buyback is a positive for 2016
at least. We would expect shares to outperform this morning, though
tempered by comments on future buyback potential, revenue outlook and the
2% QoQ fall in NAV.

BE

And MOST.

11:16 am
BE

A surprise $2.5bn buyback (2% of market cap) is a signal of confidence in the
strength of the capital position of the bank, though new guidance for flat
dividends for the 'foreseeable future' does send a cautious message on the
growth outlook. The postponement of the 10% ROE target was already
expected (consensus 2017 ROE is 6.1%) but a lack of new timetable to achieve
this ambition is disappointing. Adjusted operating profit of $5.36bn was 9%
ahead of consensus due to better revenues +3% ahead of expectation, flat q/q
with resilent GB&M and wealth revenues. Cost were in-line and impairment
marginally higher than expected (54bps). The CET1 was solid at 12.8% (pro-
forma for Brazil). Overall we see little to excite given revenue headwinds in 2H
(seasonality fall in GBP Brazil exit etc) and we note the buyback is likely
smaller than the scrip dividend so share count is still likely to rise from here.

BE

Buyback of $2.5bn tempered by more cautious dividend policy: We see
this a a cautious signal around the growth outlook as current surplus capital
cannot be profitably deployed and future earnings growth needed to support
the previous progressive dividend policy is hard to come by. HSBC came out
with a strong capital print of 12.8% (proforma for the Brazil exit) and have
announced a share buyback of $2.5bn costing c.24bps on the CET1 ratio and at
current prices buying back 1.9% of the shares. We see this as an encouraging
sign of confidence around the capital position of the group and ability to deal
with future regulatory changes e.g. Basel IV / IFRS 9 etc. However, the size is
not that material and the buyback, only going some way to neutralising the
scrip component of the dividend which was $2.03bn over the last 12 months.
HSBC have changed the dividend policy from being progressive to flat "the
Board is planning in this environment on the basis of sustaining the annual
dividend in respect of the year at its current level for the foreseeable future."
meaning that earnings may not be able to grow to support the dividend and
we note the headroom on BoCom has fallen from $1.7bn to $0.8bn as the VIU
fell due to higher impairment assumptions which means derecognition of the
associate income is looking more likely.

BE

Adjusted group revenues were broadly stable q/q but fell c.9% y/y (5%
constant currency) largely due to weaker wealth management and equities
business out of Asia. The quarterly trend was encouraging and a strong beat to
consensus which was looking for -3% y/y. RBWM proved particularly strong
(4% ahead of MSe) despite strong competition in key markets with a pick up in
wealth management in the core business (+13% constant currency), while the
US run-off portfolio revenues moved back to positive. GBM trends were mixed
within the markets businesses (-13% y/y, +8% q/q) with strong credit
revenues +14% y/y, steady rates and FX but weakness in equities (-57% y/y, -
10% q/q).

BE

11:21 am
BE

Have some Citi.

BE

STAN 1H16 PBT of $0.9bn headline and $1.0bn underlying is ahead of our expectations. For us the equity story of STAN here is all about cost efficiency and credit quality (and linked to the latter capital improvement). Importantly operating expenses $4.5bn was 10% lower YoY and 8% better than our forecast. Provisions $1.3bn is 22% lower YoY. CET1 13.1% +50bps YTD and 20bps ahead of our estimate. NPL ratio improved 10bps YTD to 4.9%.

BE

2Q16 saw a qoq uptick in loan losses to $825m (vs $471m in 1Q16), but remain well below the 2Q-4Q15 levels. These loan losses include a $93m charge on the liquidation portfolio (after $107m 1Q16), which has shrunk by 3% qoq to $7.3bn. On the ‘ongoing business’ the NPL ratio has increased from 2.2% to 2.3% qoq and coverage ratio increased from 61% to 62%.

11:21 am
BE

CET1 ratio is flat qoq at 13.1%, at the upper-end of StanChart’s target range of 12-13%. This is due to another 1% qoq reduction in RWAs, together with retained earnings, offset by regulatory deductions and “net other movements”. Restructuring charges to-date total almost $2bn. A further c$1bn is anticipated, mainly relating to expected loss on sale of the liquidation portfolio.

BE

Stan's better capitalised than HSBC. Is that right?

BE

1H16 results (both profits and capital) are reassuring signs that the STAN recovery story is underway. CEO comment that “it is likely to take longer than we had hoped to reach” their ROE targets of 8% in 2018 and 10% in 2020 are not a concern as consensus ROE forecast is 5.7% for 2018. CEO reiterates that they “remain confident that the actions we set out in November last year will eventually allow us to generate returns in excess of our cost of capital

11:22 am
BE

Jefferies questioning the quality of the beat.

BE

2Q – Revenue sustained by low-quality sources. STAN’s 2Q16 results show a revenue
base annualising at $13.9bn (vs ‘18E implied management target of $17bn), in-line with
consensus. In 2Q, revenue fell 15% YoY at the group level, a deceleration from quarters past.
However, revenues are presently sustained by asset & liability management (up 27% YoY),
corporate finance (+21% YoY) and “other” line items. Trends in core businesses such as trade
finance and cash management were worse QoQ and YoY, with trade finance revenues down
24% and cash management down 14% YoY. We would have expected a somewhat better
performance in FX where revenues were down 28% QoQ and YoY. Our call remains that
revenues have stabilised but are not yet showing a path to growth. We believe that meeting
both Street and company 2018 expectations remains a substantial stretch.

BE

The fall in ITV’s share price has spurred takeover talk. A possible candidate that could potentially buy the whole company is RTL. According to our scenario RTL would only buy the content from ITV Studios and draft in Liberty Global as the natural owner of ITV's TV assets. We run through the rationale for such a deal, without changing estimates. We show how the EPS accretion means it makes sense for RTL and explain why Liberty is the better owner for ITV TV.

BE

Fremantle's hunt for scripted

Hit by 2015’s programme fatigue, FremantleMedia (FMT) reacted quickly and acquired a whole bunch of smaller production assets. Is ITV Studios the next asset on the list? ITV’s current valuation, driven by the combination of a lower share price and weak sterling, make it an interesting target that would fit with FMT's strategy of scripted content acquisition.

PM

BE

M&A would be EPS accretive

We put a 12x EBITA multiple on ITV Studios, which we believe is justified given the IP-load and the margins that are competitive to typical broadcasting margins. On our M&A scenario the ITV Studios acquisition would be 12% EPS accretive to RTL numbers in 2016.

BE

Which is an argument, I guess, though one has to remember that Liberum's a buyer 30% above where ITV currently trades. It's quite motivated to make arguments.

BE

BE

Here's Canaccord.

11:48 am
BE

GAME Digital reported continuing challenging conditions in its H2, likely resulting in
Ebitda at the lower end of the range of market expectations. As expected, there was
material decline in low margin console sales during H2 (down over 20%), however,
ongoing sales of both mint and pre-owned content remained disappointingly soft, down
by a combined 5% YoY. And good growth in its Gametronics (pre-owned technology sales
grew 65%) and Accessories (Toys to Life etc helped fuel 20% growth) was insufficient to
off-set the impact. In addition, costs were up YoY, reflecting ongoing investment in the
Multiplay/eSports business, where pay-back will not start to come through until 2018.
Group revenues will therefore be down by around 6%, driving a c.40% decline YoY in
Ebitda to a projected £28.1m, compared with our previous £32.2m (and a bottom-of-the-
range £26.2m).

BE

Looking out to FY17, management talks of negotiating improved terms with some key
suppliers, as well as focusing on operational efficiencies and cost savings. However,
given increased investment in Multiplay, and the planned launch of new in-store live
gaming activities (where we anticipate a combined impact of £3m), Ebitda in FY17 will
fall (albeit broadly level LfL).
One positive was that year end net cash was modestly above expectations at £40m,
and GAME has secured a third party £75m financing facility (replacing the proposed
£100m facility from GAME's largest shareholder, Elliott), providing long-term (up to 2020)
working capital funding - although we still anticipate GAME to remain cash positive even
at the nadir of its working capital cycle.

BE

A soft pipeline of new games through its H2, combined with the inevitable impact of poor
weather reducing high street footfall, have provided a challenging backdrop for GAME.
The Spanish business has traded well (double-digit underlying growth) and the UK gained
market share. Nonetheless, we see material downgrades. Our FY16F PBT (norm) comes
down from £20.6m/9.3p to £16.5m/7.3p (and dividend 3.3p), while FY17F falls from
£19.7m/9.0p to £12.4m/5.5p.

11:49 am
BE

GAME shares are down by 40% since its interims in March and on our revised forecasts,
it trades on a calendarised 2016 PER of 11.1x and EV/Ebitda of just 3.1x, relative to the
UK Hardline/Speciality average of 15.6x/8.3x.
We downgrade our TP from 92p to 72p to reflect the downgrades, putting it on a 30%
sub-sector discount (2016F PER of 11.0x, and a 4.5% yield) to reflect the increased risk
profile. But we would expect to see further short-term weakness. HOLD.

11:58 am
BE

There's Drax, which usually has a following on the right for reasons I never understand.

BE

Citi negative.

BE

UK utilities (+12% YTD) have benefited from their safe haven status and a recovery of commodity prices, neither of which are justified based on the fundamentals or sustainable in the long term, in our view. Political and/or regulatory environment could surprise on the downside with risks of a windfall tax on water networks and regulatory review kicking off later this month. We see better value elsewhere – Continental European utilities.

12:00 pm
BE

Commodity glass ceiling

Sentiment has materially improved since February lows, but the outlook remains unchanged: we still expect 35-55bcm of LNG to land in Europe, Gazprom to increase volumes to the UK and coal prices to be in structural decline. This combined with falling power demand does not bode well for the long-term outlook for UK gas and power prices, in our view.

Expensive defensives

The premium ratings of regulated utilities are increasingly looking unsupported by their fundamentals. Both regulatory and political risks are on the rise and we would not rule out the risk of a one-off windfall tax on network utilities (especially waters) or a claw back of the excess gains on tax and interest in the context of a more centralist government.

Retail: political risks subsiding for now

Following the CMA decision, political risks appears to have subsided. However, it’s only a matter of time before they resurface with retail energy bills set to increase, in our view.

We see better value outside of the UK

Given the excessive valuations in the regulated names and lack of attractive growth from the integrated players, we see better value in Europe. We upgrade SSE to Neutral given its c12% underperformance YTD and lack of short-term catalyst. We downgrade UU to Sell given our view of regulatory and political risk. We downgrade DRX to Sell as we see downside risks to current commodity prices. We also see downside risk to NG shares, but keep our Neutral rating for now due to the lack of visible catalyst.

BE

Self explanatory really.

SSE PLC (SSE:LSE): Last: 1,513, up 10 (+0.67%), High: 1,532, Low: 1,507, Volume: 1.17m
12:00 pm

BE

Oh, and I wanted to mention GVC as well.

12:02 pm
GVC Holdings PLC (GVC:LSE): Last: 677.00, up 13.5 (+2.03%), High: 687.00, Low: 661.50, Volume: 907.59k
PM

gaming?

BE

Yep, gambling largely in markets where regulation is unclear.

12:03 pm
BE

We have voiced longstanding doubts about this thing, and we've been wrong. Spectacularly wrong.

BE

It's gone from 450p to 650p in a year. Record high today, again.

PM

hmm

12:04 pm
BE

Liberum's providing today's push.

PM

Bwin paying off

BE

GVC is a unique quoted gaming operator in terms of
geographic diversity and exposure to growth markets; only
c.10% of customers from the UK means it is the least
exposed of any peer to the risk of increasing duty/regulation
in its domestic market. The synergy benefits of bwin are
substantial and we expect EPS to more than double
between FY16 and FY18. Our TP of 738p is prudently
calculated using multiples at a discount to peers.

12:05 pm
BE

Investment summary

• Access to high growth markets - most other quoted operators have
much higher exposure to the very profitable but highly competitive and
maturing UK market. However, c.90% of GVC customers are outside of
the UK.

• Brexit - As a consequence of the international spread of businesses, there
are no significant implications to the Group of the UK’s decision to leave
the EU.

• Pure online play - GVC’s sole focus on online means it has no exposure
to the slower growth and regulatory challenges faced by the UK Retail
operators.

• Management have identified major cost synergy benefits from the
acquisition of bwin.party - the recent trading update confirms that GVC is
on track to deliver promised synergies on the merger which completed on
February 1st; combining the two Groups yields savings of €125m.

• Revenue upside - Bwin has historically underachieved on cross selling
gaming to sportsbook customers. Increasing the cross-sell rate from
c.30% to 40% by FY18 underpins our forecasts.

• Forecasts above consensus - As a consequence of factoring in the
increase in cross-sell, our Group revenue estimates for both FY17 and
FY18 are above the current consensus by 2%-3% and for EBITDA by 4-
5%.

• Risk to forecasts on the upside - Despite our above consensus forecasts
we believe that there is upside risk to estimates given the growth
prospects which exist in the markets which GVC operates in. This is
opposite to the heavily exposed UK operators which will likely have
regulatory and duty challenges in the future.

• B2B Opportunities - In addition, while we have implicitly factored in some
very modest revenues, these do not reflect the potential as evidenced by
the recent deal with Betfred.

• History of execution on major deals - GVC has a successful record of
execution on M&A transactions most notably with the transformational
acquisition of the Sportingbet assets in 2013. This lends confidence in
Management’s capacity to replicate this with the integration of bwin.party
and we expect more M&A activity in the future.

• Cash flow potential - Whilst the acquisition of bwin.party beds down and
given the relatively high cost of associated debt, GVC is not planning on a
dividend to shareholders for 2016. However from FY17, the Company is
targeting a 50% pay-out ratio which would put the shares on a yield of
c.3% growing to over 4% in 2018.

• Valuation - 2016 will be a year of bedding down the bwin acquisition albeit
at the same time, operating metrics from H1 demonstrate strong
momentum; pro forma NGR grew 11% in constant currency. Our PT of
738p is based on a range of earnings-based multiples (all at a discount to
the peer group average) and DCF. Meanwhile, a P/E and EV/EBITDA
multiple in FY18 of 10x and 7x respectively reflects the rapid growth over
the period.

BE

I do feel we're in some kind of parallel universe where brokers can talk about having nearly 50% of revenue from unregulated markets as a positive.

BE

12:07 pm
BE

Still. Market clearly disagrees. So, fair enough.

12:07 pm
PM

BE

ITV TV goes to Liberty

The acquisition of UTV Ireland earlier in July can be read as a sign that Liberty’s intention is to diversify its revenue mix into broadcasting. It is clear that J. Malone’s, the chairman of Liberty, interest in the UK advertising market is unchanged - he even sees it as an opportunity post-Brexit. Liberty currently owns a 9.9% in ITV. Liberty bought a 6.4% stake in 2014, which it increased to its current holding in July 2015.
